Separating cycles and isoperimetric
inequalities in the uniform infinite
planar quadrangulation

Abstract

We study geometric properties of the infinite random lattice called the uniform infinite planar quadrangulation or UIPQ. We establish a precise form of a conjecture of Krikun stating that the minimal size of a cycle that separates the ball of radius Rğ‘…R centered at the root vertex from infinity grows linearly in Rğ‘…R. As a consequence, we derive certain isoperimetric bounds showing that the boundary size of any simply connected set Ağ´A consisting of a finite union of faces of the UIPQ and containing the root vertex is bounded below by a (random) constant times |A|1/4â€‹(logâ¡|A|)âˆ’(3/4)âˆ’Î´superscriptğ´14superscriptğ´34ğ›¿|A|^{1/4}(\log|A|)^{-(3/4)-\delta}, where the volume |A|ğ´|A| is the number of faces in Ağ´A.

1 Introduction

In the recent years, much work has been devoted to discrete and continuous models of random geometry in two dimensions. Two of the most popular discrete models are the uniform infinite planar triangulation (or UIPT), which was introduced by Angel and Schramm [1, 2] and in fact motivated much of the subsequent work, and the uniform infinite planar quadrangulation (or UIPQ). In the present work, we concentrate on the UIPQ, although we believe that our methods can be adapted to give similar results for the UIPT. Roughly speaking, the UIPQ is a random infinite graph embedded in the plane, such that all faces (connected components of the complement of edges) are quadrangles, possibly with two edges glued together. See Fig.4 below for an illustration of what the UIPQ may look like near its root vertex. We study certain geometric properties of the UIPQ, concerning the existence of â€œsmallâ€ cycles that separate a large ball centered at the root vertex from infinity, with applications to isoperimetric inequalities.

The starting point of our work is a conjecture of Krikun in the paper [14] which provided the first construction of the UIPQ as the local limit of uniform planar quadrangulations with a fixed number of faces (another construction was suggested by Chassaing and Durhuus [3], and the equivalence between the two approaches was established by MÃ©nard [18] â€” see also [9] for a third construction). Denote the UIPQ by ğ’«ğ’«{\mathcal{P}}, and, for every integer râ‰¥1ğ‘Ÿ1r\geq 1, let Brâ€‹(ğ’«)subscriptğµğ‘Ÿğ’«B_{r}({\mathcal{P}}) stand for the ball of radius rğ‘Ÿr centered at the root vertex, which is defined as the union of all faces that are incident to at least one vertex whose graph distance from the root is at most râˆ’1ğ‘Ÿ1r-1. The complement of the ball Brâ€‹(ğ’«)subscriptğµğ‘Ÿğ’«B_{r}({\mathcal{P}}) is in general not connected, but there is a unique unbounded component, whose boundary is called the exterior boundary of the ball. The set inside the exterior boundary, which may be obtained by filling in the â€œbounded holesâ€ of the ball, is called the (standard) hull of radius rğ‘Ÿr and will be denoted by Brâˆ™â€‹(ğ’«)subscriptsuperscriptğµâˆ™ğ‘Ÿğ’«B^{\bullet}_{r}({\mathcal{P}}). It is known that the size of the exterior boundary, that is, the number of edges in this boundary, grows like r2superscriptğ‘Ÿ2r^{2} when râ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘Ÿr\to\infty: See [7] for more precise asymptotics obtained both for the UIPT and the UIPQ. On the other hand, Krikun constructed a cycle that separates the ball Brâ€‹(ğ’«)subscriptğµğ‘Ÿğ’«B_{r}({\mathcal{P}}) from infinity and whose size grows linearly in rğ‘Ÿr when rğ‘Ÿr is large. Here we say that a cycle ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C} made of edges of the UIPQ separates a finite set Ağ´A of vertices from infinity if Ağ´A does not intersect ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C} but any path from a vertex of Ağ´A to infinity intersects ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C} (see Fig.Â 1 for a schematic illustration). Krikun conjectured that the cycle he constructed is essentially the shortest possible, meaning that the minimal size of a cycle that separates the ball Brâ€‹(ğ’«)subscriptğµğ‘Ÿğ’«B_{r}({\mathcal{P}}) from infinity must be linear in rğ‘Ÿr. A weak form of this conjecture was derived in [5], but the results of this paper did not exclude the possibility that a ball could be separated from infinity by a small cycle lying â€œvery far awayâ€ from the ball.

The following theorem provides quantitative estimates that confirm Krikunâ€™s conjecture.

Part (ii) of the theorem is proved by using the separating cycle introduced by Krikun and sharpening the estimates in [14]. So the most interesting part of the theorem is part (i). We believe that our condition Î´<2ğ›¿2\delta<2 is close to optimal, in the sense that, for Rğ‘…R large, â„™â€‹(Lâ€‹(R)â‰¤Îµâ€‹R)â„™ğ¿ğ‘…ğœ€ğ‘…{\mathbb{P}}(L(R)\leq\varepsilon R) should behave like Îµ2superscriptğœ€2\varepsilon^{2}, possibly up to logarithmic corrections. The proof of part (i) relies on a technical estimate which is of independent interest and that we now present. We first label vertices of the UIPQ by their distances from the root vertex, and for every integer râ‰¥1ğ‘Ÿ1r\geq 1, we say that a face of the UIPQ is rğ‘Ÿr-simple if the labels of the vertices incident to this face take the three values râˆ’1,r,r+1ğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿ1r-1,r,r+1 (note that there are faces such that labels of incident vertices take only two values, these faces are called confluent in [4]). In each rğ‘Ÿr-simple face, we draw a â€œdiagonalâ€ connecting the two corners labeled rğ‘Ÿr (these two corners may correspond to the same vertex), and such diagonals, which are not edges of the UIPQ, are called rğ‘Ÿr-diagonals. Then, there is a â€œmaximalâ€ cycle made of rğ‘Ÿr-diagonals, which is simple and such that the labels of vertices lying in the unbounded component of the complement of this cycle are at least r+1ğ‘Ÿ1r+1. We denote this maximal cycle by ğ’rsubscriptğ’ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{C}_{r}, and, for 1â‰¤r<râ€²1ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²1\leq r<r^{\prime}, we define the annulus ğ’â€‹(r,râ€²)ğ’ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²\mathcal{C}(r,r^{\prime}) as the part of the UIPQ between the cycles ğ’rsubscriptğ’ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{C}_{r} and ğ’râ€²subscriptğ’superscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²\mathcal{C}_{r^{\prime}}. See Section 2 below for more precise definitions. Note that the cycles ğ’rsubscriptğ’ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{C}_{r} are not made of edges of the UIPQ in contrast with the separating cycles that we consider in Theorem 1 and in the next proposition.

Proposition 2.

Let Î²âˆˆ(0,3)ğ›½03\beta\in(0,3). There exists a constant CÎ²â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ¶â€²ğ›½C^{\prime}_{\beta} such that, for every integer râ‰¥1ğ‘Ÿ1r\geq 1 and for every integer nâ‰¥1ğ‘›1n\geq 1, the probability that there exists a cycle of the UIPQ of length smaller than rğ‘Ÿr, which is contained in ğ’â€‹(nâ€‹r,(n+2)â€‹r)ğ’ğ‘›ğ‘Ÿğ‘›2ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{C}(nr,(n+2)r), does not intersect ğ’(n+2)â€‹rsubscriptğ’ğ‘›2ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{C}_{(n+2)r}, and disconnects the root vertex from infinity, is bounded above by CÎ²â€²â€‹nâˆ’Î²subscriptsuperscriptğ¶â€²ğ›½superscriptğ‘›ğ›½C^{\prime}_{\beta}\,n^{-\beta}.

The condition that the cycle does not intersect ğ’(n+2)â€‹rsubscriptğ’ğ‘›2ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{C}_{(n+2)r} is included for technical convenience, and could be removed from the statement.

The proof of Proposition 2 relies on a â€œskeleton decompositionâ€ of the UIPQ, which is already presented in the work of Krikun [14]. Our presentation is however different from the one in [14] and better suited to our purposes. We introduce and use the notion of a truncated quadrangulation, which is basically a planar map with a boundary, where all faces (distinct from the distinguished one) are quadrangles, except for those incident to the boundary, which are triangles (see Section 2.1 for precise definitions). The annulus ğ’â€‹(r,râ€²)ğ’ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²\mathcal{C}(r,r^{\prime}) can be viewed as a truncated quadrangulation of the cylinder of height râ€²âˆ’rsuperscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²ğ‘Ÿr^{\prime}-r. Our motivation for introducing truncated quadrangulations comes from the fact that they allow certain explicit calculations in the UIPQ. For every integer râ‰¥1ğ‘Ÿ1r\geq 1, we define the â€œtruncated hullâ€ of radius rğ‘Ÿr of the UIPQ, which is basically the part of the UIPQ inside the maximal cycle ğ’rsubscriptğ’ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{C}_{r} (see Section 2.2 for a precise definition). This truncated hull is different from the standard hull Brâˆ™â€‹(ğ’«)subscriptsuperscriptğµâˆ™ğ‘Ÿğ’«B^{\bullet}_{r}({\mathcal{P}}) introduced above, which had been considered in [6, 7] in particular, but it is essentially the same object as the hull defined in [14]. It turns out that it is possible to compute the law of the truncated hull in a rather explicit manner (Corollary 8) and in particular the law of the perimeter of the hull has a very simple form (Proposition 11). These calculations make heavy use of the skeleton decomposition of the UIPQ, and more generally of the similar decomposition for truncated quadrangulations of the cylinder. This decomposition involves a forest structure, which was already described by Krikun [14, Section 3.2] and is similar to the one for triangulations that was discovered in [13] and heavily used in the recent work [8] dealing with first-passage percolation on the UIPT.

Given the forest structure associated with a truncated quadrangulation of the cylinder, the idea of the proof of Proposition 2 is as follows. One first observes that, with high probability, there exist, for some Î´>0ğ›¿0\delta>0, more than nÎ´superscriptğ‘›ğ›¿n^{\delta} trees with maximal height in the forest coding the annulus ğ’â€‹(nâ€‹r,(n+2)â€‹r)ğ’ğ‘›ğ‘Ÿğ‘›2ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{C}(nr,(n+2)r). For each of these trees, one can find a vertex on the cycle ğ’nâ€‹rsubscriptğ’ğ‘›ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{C}_{nr} (the interior boundary of the annulus) which is connected to the exterior boundary ğ’(n+2)â€‹rsubscriptğ’ğ‘›2ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{C}_{(n+2)r} by a path of length 2â€‹r2ğ‘Ÿ2r. Assuming that there is a cycle of length rğ‘Ÿr in the annulus that disconnects the root vertex from infinity, it follows that any two of these particular vertices of ğ’nâ€‹rsubscriptğ’ğ‘›ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{C}_{nr} can be connected by a path staying in the annulus with length at most 5â€‹r5ğ‘Ÿ5r. Results of Curien and Miermont [10] about the graph distances between boundary points in infinite quadrangulations with a boundary, show that this cannot occur except on a set of small probability.

Our lower bounds on the minimal size of separating cycles lead to interesting isoperimetric inequalities showing informally that the size of the boundary of a simply connected set which is a finite union of faces and contains the root vertex must be at least of the order of the volume raised to the power 1/4141/4. The fact that we cannot do better than the power 1/4141/4 follows from part (ii) in Theorem 1, since it is well known [3, 6, 7] that the volume of the ball, or of the standard hull, of radius rğ‘Ÿr is of order r4superscriptğ‘Ÿ4r^{4}. We refer to [17, Chapter 6] for a thorough discussion of isoperimetric inequalities on infinite graphs.

Let ğ’¦ğ’¦\mathcal{K} denote the collection of all simply connected compact subsets of the plane that are finite unions of faces of the UIPQ (including their boundaries) and contain the root vertex. For Aâˆˆğ’¦ğ´ğ’¦A\in\mathcal{K}, the volume of Ağ´A, denoted by |A|ğ´|A|, is the number of faces of the UIPQ contained in Ağ´A, and the boundary size of Ağ´A, denoted by |âˆ‚A|ğ´|\partial A|, is the number of edges in the boundary of Ağ´A.

Theorem 3.

Let Î´>0ğ›¿0\delta>0. Then,

The exponent 3434\frac{3}{4} in the statement of the theorem is presumably not the optimal one. Our method involves estimates for the tail of the distribution of the volume of the hull Brâˆ™â€‹(ğ’«)subscriptsuperscriptğµâˆ™ğ‘Ÿğ’«B^{\bullet}_{r}({\mathcal{P}}), which are derived from a first moment bound (Proposition 15). We expect that these estimates can be improved, leading to a better value of the exponent of logâ¡|A|ğ´\log|A| (the results of Riera [20] for the Brownian plane suggest that one should be able to replace 3434\frac{3}{4} by 1212\frac{1}{2} in the statement of the theorem). On the other hand, one cannot hope to replace |A|14â€‹(logâ¡|A|)âˆ’34âˆ’Î´superscriptğ´14superscriptğ´34ğ›¿|A|^{\frac{1}{4}}\,(\log|A|)^{-\frac{3}{4}-\delta} by |A|14superscriptğ´14|A|^{\frac{1}{4}} in the theorem: Simple zero-one arguments using the separating cycles introduced by Krikun [14] (see Section 2.4 below) show that there exist sets Ağ´A such that the ratio |âˆ‚A|/|A|14ğ´superscriptğ´14|\partial A|/|A|^{\frac{1}{4}} is arbitrarily small.

Still we can state the following proposition.

The proofs of both Theorem 3 and Proposition 4 rely on Theorem 1 and on the fact that the volume of the hull of radius rğ‘Ÿr is of order r4superscriptğ‘Ÿ4r^{4}. Assuming that |âˆ‚A|ğ´|\partial A| is small, then either the root vertex is sufficiently far from âˆ‚Ağ´\partial A, which implies that a large ball centered at the root vertex is disconnected from infinity by the small cycle âˆ‚Ağ´\partial A (so that we can use the estimate of Theorem 1) or the root vertex is close to âˆ‚Ağ´\partial A, but then it follows that the whole set Ağ´A is contained in the standard hull of radius (approximately) equal to the distance from the root vertex to âˆ‚Ağ´\partial A, which implies that the volume of Ağ´A cannot be too big (at this point of the argument, in the proof of Theorem 3, we need estimates for the tail of the distribution of the volume of hulls).

The paper is organized as follows. Section 2 presents a number of preliminaries, concerning truncated quadrangulations, their relations with the UIPQ and their skeleton decompositions, and a number of related calculations. As mentioned earlier, this section owes a lot to the work of Krikun [14], and in particular we make use of enumeration results derived in [14]. One additional motivation for deriving the results of Section 2 in a somewhat more precise form than in [14] is the fact that we plan to use these results in a forthcoming work [16] on local modifications of distances in the UIPQ, in the spirit of [8]. Proposition 2 is proved in Section 3, and part (i) of Theorem 1 easily follows from this proposition. Section 4 is devoted to the proof of part (ii) of Theorem 1. This proof relies on the explicit calculation of the distribution of the number of trees with maximal height in the forest coding the annulus ğ’â€‹(r,râ€²)ğ’ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²\mathcal{C}(r,r^{\prime}) (Proposition 14). This calculation is also used to give an easy lower bound for the probability â„™â€‹(Lâ€‹(R)â‰¤Îµâ€‹R)â„™ğ¿ğ‘…ğœ€ğ‘…{\mathbb{P}}(L(R)\leq\varepsilon R). Section 5 contains the proof of Proposition 4 and Theorem 3. An important ingredient of the proof of Theorem 3 is Proposition 15, which provides a first moment bound for the volume of hulls. Finally, the Appendix gives the proof of a technical lemma stated at the end of Section 2, which plays an important role in Section 3.

2 Preliminaries

2.1 Truncated quadrangulations

We will consider truncated quadrangulations. Informally, these are quadrangulations with a simple boundary, where the quadrangles incident to the boundary are replaced by triangles. A more precise definition is as follows.

Definition 2.1.

Let pâ‰¥1ğ‘1p\geq 1 be an integer. A truncated quadrangulation with boundary size pğ‘p is a planar map â„³â„³\mathcal{M} having a distinguished face ğ”£ğ”£\mathfrak{f} with a simple boundary of size pğ‘p such that:

  1. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    Each edge of the boundary of ğ”£ğ”£\mathfrak{f} is incident both to ğ”£ğ”£\mathfrak{f} and to a triangular face of â„³â„³\mathcal{M} and these triangular faces are distinct.

  2. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    All faces other than ğ”£ğ”£\mathfrak{f} and the triangular faces incident to the boundary of ğ”£ğ”£\mathfrak{f} have degree 444.

It will be convenient to view truncated quadrangulations as drawn in the plane in such a way that the distinguished face is the unbounded face. With this convention, we will always assume that a truncated quadrangulation is rooted and, unless otherwise specified, that the root edge lies on the boundary of the distinguished face and is oriented clockwise. See Fig.2 for an example. Faces distinct from the distinguished face are called inner faces, and vertices that do not lie on the boundary of the distinguished face are called inner vertices.

Notice that, when pâ‰¥2ğ‘2p\geq 2, any of the triangular faces incident to the boundary of ğ”£ğ”£\mathfrak{f} must be nondegenerate (i.e. its boundary cannot contain a loop). Furthermore, a simple argument shows that each of these triangular faces is incident to an inner vertex. The last property clearly also holds if p=1ğ‘1p=1. Hence a truncated quadrangulation with boundary size pâ‰¥1ğ‘1p\geq 1 must have at least one inner vertex.

We notice that our truncated quadrangulations with boundary size pğ‘p are in one-to-one correspondence with the â€œquadrangulations with a simple boundaryâ€ of size 2â€‹p2ğ‘2p considered by Krikun [14] (starting from the latter, we just â€œcutâ€ the boundary quadrangles along the appropriate diagonals to get a truncated quadrangulation). If we add an extra vertex vâˆ—subscriptğ‘£v_{*} inside the face ğ”£ğ”£\mathfrak{f}, then draw an edge from each vertex of the boundary of ğ”£ğ”£\mathfrak{f} to vâˆ—subscriptğ‘£v_{*}, and finally remove all edges of the boundary of ğ”£ğ”£\mathfrak{f}, we get a plane quadrangulation and hence a bipartite graph: In particular, it follows that, if vğ‘£v and vâ€²superscriptğ‘£â€²v^{\prime} are two adjacent inner vertices of â„³â„³\mathcal{M}, their distances from the boundary differ by 111. This observation will be useful later.

For integers nâ‰¥1ğ‘›1n\geq 1 and pâ‰¥1ğ‘1p\geq 1, we let â„šn,ptrsubscriptsuperscriptâ„štrğ‘›ğ‘{\mathbb{Q}}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{n,p} be the set of all (rooted) truncated quadrangulations with boundary size pğ‘p and nğ‘›n inner faces.

We need another definition.

Definition 2.2.

Let h,p,qâ‰¥1â„ğ‘ğ‘1h,p,q\geq 1 be positive integers. A truncated quadrangulation of the cylinder of height hâ„h with boundary sizes (p,q)ğ‘ğ‘(p,q) is a planar map ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q} having two distinguished faces ğ”£bsubscriptğ”£ğ‘\mathfrak{f}_{b} and ğ”£tsubscriptğ”£ğ‘¡\mathfrak{f}_{t} such that:

  1. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    The face ğ”£bsubscriptğ”£ğ‘\mathfrak{f}_{b} (called the bottom face) has a simple boundary of size pğ‘p, which is called the bottom cycle, and the face ğ”£tsubscriptğ”£ğ‘¡\mathfrak{f}_{t} (called the top face) has a simple boundary of size qğ‘q, which is called the top cycle.

  2. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    Each edge of the bottom cycle (resp. of the top cycle) is incident both to ğ”£bsubscriptğ”£ğ‘\mathfrak{f}_{b} (resp. to ğ”£tsubscriptğ”£ğ‘¡\mathfrak{f}_{t}) and to a triangular face of ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q} and these triangular faces are distinct.

  3. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    All faces other than ğ”£bsubscriptğ”£ğ‘\mathfrak{f}_{b}, ğ”£tsubscriptğ”£ğ‘¡\mathfrak{f}_{t}, and the triangular faces incident to the bottom and top cycles, have degree 444.

  4. âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    Every vertex of the top cycle is at graph distance exactly hâ„h from the bottom cycle, and every edge of the top cycle is incident to a triangular face containing a vertex at graph distance hâˆ’1â„1h-1 from the bottom cycle.

By definition, the inner faces of ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q} are all faces except the two distinguished ones. The last assertion of Definition 2.2 shows that the top face and the bottom face do not play a symmetric role. We will implicitly assume that truncated quadrangulations of the cylinder of height hâ„h are drawn in the plane so that the top face is the unbounded face, and that they are rooted in such a way that the root edge lies on the bottom cycle and is oriented clockwise. See Fig.3 for an example.

In a way similar to the truncated quadrangulations of Definition 2.1, the triangular face associated with an edge of the bottom cycle must contain a vertex which does not belong to this cycle. The same holds for the top cycle â€” this is obvious from the last assertion of Definition 2.2.

2.2 Truncated quadrangulations in the UIPQ

Let us now explain why the definitions of the previous section are relevant to our study of the UIPQ. We label vertices of the UIPQ by their graph distance from the root vertex. Then the labels of corners incident to a face (enumerated in cyclic order along the boundary of the face) are of the type k,kâˆ’1,k,kâˆ’1ğ‘˜ğ‘˜1ğ‘˜ğ‘˜1k,k-1,k,k-1 or k,k+1,k,kâˆ’1ğ‘˜ğ‘˜1ğ‘˜ğ‘˜1k,k+1,k,k-1 for some integer kâ‰¥1ğ‘˜1k\geq 1, and the face is called kğ‘˜k-simple in the second case. Fix an integer râ‰¥1ğ‘Ÿ1r\geq 1. For every rğ‘Ÿr-simple face, we draw a diagonal between the two corners labeled rğ‘Ÿr in this face, and these diagonals are called rğ‘Ÿr-diagonals. If vğ‘£v is a vertex incident to an rğ‘Ÿr-diagonal (equivalently, if vğ‘£v has label rğ‘Ÿr and is incident to an rğ‘Ÿr-simple face), then a simple combinatorial argument shows that the number of rğ‘Ÿr-diagonals incident to vğ‘£v is even â€” to be precise, we need to count this number with multiplicities, since rğ‘Ÿr-diagonals may be loops. It follows that the collection of all rğ‘Ÿr-diagonals can be obtained as the union of a collection of disjoint simple cycles (disjoint here means that no edge is shared by two of these cycles). See Fig.4 for an example.

Lemma 5.

There is a unique simple cycle made of rğ‘Ÿr-diagonals such that the unbounded component of the complement of this cycle contains no rğ‘Ÿr-diagonal and no vertex at distance less than or equal to rğ‘Ÿr from the root vertex. This cycle will be called the maximal cycle made of rğ‘Ÿr-diagonals and will be denoted by ğ’rsubscriptğ’ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{C}_{r}.

Proof.

It suffices to verify that the root vertex lies inside a bounded component of the complement of some cycle made of rğ‘Ÿr-diagonals (this cycle may be taken to be simple and then satisfies the properties stated in the lemma). To this end, consider a geodesic Î³ğ›¾\gamma from the root vertex to infinity and write vrsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿv_{r}, resp. vrâˆ’1,vr+1subscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿ1subscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿ1v_{r-1},v_{r+1}, for the unique vertex of Î³ğ›¾\gamma at distance rğ‘Ÿr, resp. râˆ’1,r+1ğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘Ÿ1r-1,r+1, from the root vertex. Also write vrâ€‹vrâˆ’1subscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿ1{v_{r}v_{r-1}}, resp. vrâ€‹vr+1subscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿ1{v_{r}v_{r+1}}, for the edge of Î³ğ›¾\gamma incident to vrsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿv_{r} and vrâˆ’1subscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿ1v_{r-1}, resp. to vrsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿv_{r} and vr+1subscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿ1v_{r+1}. Let k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1}, resp. k2subscriptğ‘˜2k_{2}, denote the number of rğ‘Ÿr-diagonals incident to vrsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿv_{r} that lie between vrâ€‹vr+1subscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿ1{v_{r}v_{r+1}} and vrâ€‹vrâˆ’1subscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿ1{v_{r}v_{r-1}}, resp. between vrâ€‹vrâˆ’1subscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿ1{v_{r}v_{r-1}} and vrâ€‹vr+1subscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿ1{v_{r}v_{r+1}}, when turning around vrsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿv_{r} in clockwise order (self-loops are counted twice). An easy combinatorial argument shows that both k1subscriptğ‘˜1k_{1} and k2subscriptğ‘˜2k_{2} are odd. It follows that there must exist a cycle made of rğ‘Ÿr-diagonals that starts with an edge lying between vrâ€‹vr+1subscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿ1{v_{r}v_{r+1}} and vrâ€‹vrâˆ’1subscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿ1{v_{r}v_{r-1}} (in clockwise order) and ends with an edge lying between vrâ€‹vrâˆ’1subscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿ1{v_{r}v_{r-1}} and vrâ€‹vr+1subscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿ1{v_{r}v_{r+1}}. Simple topological considerations now show that the root vertex, and in fact the whole geodesic path Î³ğ›¾\gamma up to vertex vrâˆ’1subscriptğ‘£ğ‘Ÿ1v_{r-1} must lie in a bounded component of the complement of this cycle. âˆ

If we now add all edges of ğ’rsubscriptğ’ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{C}_{r} to the UIPQ and then remove all edges that lie in the unbounded component of the complement of ğ’rsubscriptğ’ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{C}_{r}, we get a truncated quadrangulation in the sense of Definition 2.1 (with the minor difference that, assuming that we keep the same root as in the UIPQ, the root edge does not belong to the boundary of the distinguished face). This truncated quadrangulation is called the truncated hull of radius rğ‘Ÿr and is denoted by â„‹rtrsubscriptsuperscriptâ„‹trğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{r}. Its boundary size (the length of ğ’rsubscriptğ’ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{C}_{r}) is called the perimeter of the hull and denoted by Hrsubscriptğ»ğ‘ŸH_{r}. Notice that, by construction, any vertex belonging to the boundary of the distinguished face is at distance exactly rğ‘Ÿr from the root vertex. Furthermore, for any vertex vğ‘£v of the UIPQ that does not belong to â„‹rtrsubscriptsuperscriptâ„‹trğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{r} (equivalently, that lies in the unbounded component of the complement of ğ’rsubscriptğ’ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{C}_{r}) there exists a path going from vğ‘£v to infinity that visits only vertices with label at least rğ‘Ÿr. This property follows from the fact that any two points of ğ’rsubscriptğ’ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{C}_{r} are connected by a path that visits only vertices with label at least rğ‘Ÿr.

We may and will sometimes view the truncated hull â„‹rtrsubscriptsuperscriptâ„‹trğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{r} as a quadrangulation of the cylinder: To this end, we just split the root edge into a double edge, and insert a loop (based on the root vertex) inside the resulting 222-gon. This yields a truncated quadrangulation of the cylinder of height rğ‘Ÿr with boundary sizes (1,Hr)1subscriptğ»ğ‘Ÿ(1,H_{r}), whose top cycle is ğ’rsubscriptğ’ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{C}_{r}. The root edge is the inserted loop as required in our conventions. See Fig.5 for an illustration.

Similarly, if 1â‰¤r<râ€²1ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²1\leq r<r^{\prime}, we can consider the part of the UIPQ that lies between the cycles ğ’rsubscriptğ’ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{C}_{r} and ğ’râ€²subscriptğ’superscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²\mathcal{C}_{r^{\prime}}. More precisely, we add all edges of ğ’rsubscriptğ’ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{C}_{r} and ğ’râ€²subscriptğ’superscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²\mathcal{C}_{r^{\prime}} to the UIPQ and then remove all edges that lie either inside the cycle ğ’rsubscriptğ’ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{C}_{r} or outside the cycle ğ’râ€²subscriptğ’superscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²\mathcal{C}_{r^{\prime}}. This gives rise to a quadrangulation of the cylinder of height râ€²âˆ’rsuperscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²ğ‘Ÿr^{\prime}-r whose bottom cycle and top cycle are ğ’rsubscriptğ’ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{C}_{r} and ğ’râ€²subscriptğ’superscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²\mathcal{C}_{r^{\prime}} respectively (we in fact need to specify the root edge on the bottom cycle, but we will come back to this later). By definition, this is the annulus ğ’â€‹(r,râ€²)ğ’ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²\mathcal{C}(r,r^{\prime}). We can extend this definition to r=0ğ‘Ÿ0r=0: The annulus ğ’â€‹(0,râ€²)ğ’0superscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²\mathcal{C}(0,r^{\prime}) is just the truncated hull â„‹râ€²trsubscriptsuperscriptâ„‹trsuperscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{r^{\prime}} viewed as a quadrangulation of the cylinder (we can also say that it is the part of the UIPQ that lies between the cycles ğ’0subscriptğ’0\mathcal{C}_{0} and ğ’râ€²subscriptğ’superscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²\mathcal{C}_{r^{\prime}}, if ğ’0subscriptğ’0\mathcal{C}_{0} consists of the loop added as explained above).

As an important remark, we note that the truncated hull of radius rğ‘Ÿr is quite different from the (usual) hull of radius rğ‘Ÿr considered e.g. in [6, 7], which is denoted by Brâˆ™â€‹(ğ’«)subscriptsuperscriptğµâˆ™ğ‘Ÿğ’«B^{\bullet}_{r}({\mathcal{P}}) and is obtained by filling in the bounded holes in the ball of radius rğ‘Ÿr (recall that the ball of radius râ‰¥1ğ‘Ÿ1r\geq 1 is obtained as the union of all faces incident to at least one vertex whose graph distance from the root vertex is at most râˆ’1ğ‘Ÿ1r-1). To avoid any ambiguity, the hull Brâˆ™â€‹(ğ’«)subscriptsuperscriptğµâˆ™ğ‘Ÿğ’«B^{\bullet}_{r}({\mathcal{P}}) will be called the standard hull of radius rğ‘Ÿr. The truncated hull can be recovered from the standard hull by considering the maximal cycle made of rğ‘Ÿr-diagonals as explained above. On the other hand, the standard hull is â€œbiggerâ€ than the truncated hull: To recover the standard hull from the truncated hull, we need to add the triangles incident to rğ‘Ÿr-diagonals that have been cut when removing the unbounded component of the complement of the maximal cycle, but also to fill in the bounded holes that may appear when adding these triangles (see Fig.4 for an example). For future use, we notice that the boundary of the standard hull Brâˆ™â€‹(ğ’«)subscriptsuperscriptğµâˆ™ğ‘Ÿğ’«B^{\bullet}_{r}({\mathcal{P}}) is a simple cycle, and that the graph distances of vertices in this cycle to the root vertex alternate between the values rğ‘Ÿr and r+1ğ‘Ÿ1r+1: Those vertices at graph distance rğ‘Ÿr also belong to the cycle ğ’rsubscriptğ’ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{C}_{r}, but in general there are other vertices of ğ’rsubscriptğ’ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{C}_{r} that do not belong to the boundary of Brâˆ™â€‹(ğ’«)subscriptsuperscriptğµâˆ™ğ‘Ÿğ’«B^{\bullet}_{r}({\mathcal{P}}) (see Fig.4).

2.3 The skeleton decomposition

We will now describe a decomposition of quadrangulations of the cylinder in layers. This is essentially due to Krikun [14] and very similar to the case of triangulations, which is treated in [13, 8]. For this reason, we will skip some details.

Let us fix a quadrangulation ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q} of the cylinder of height hâ‰¥2â„2h\geq 2 with boundary sizes (p,q)ğ‘ğ‘(p,q). Assign to each vertex a label equal to its distance from the bottom boundary. Let kâˆˆ{1,2,â€¦,hâˆ’1}ğ‘˜12â€¦â„1k\in\{1,2,\ldots,h-1\}, and consider all diagonals connecting corners labeled kğ‘˜k in kğ‘˜k-simple faces (defined in exactly the same manner as in the previous section for the UIPQ). As in the case of the UIPQ described above, these diagonals form a collection of cycles, and there is a maximal cycle which is simple and has the property that the unbounded component of the complement of this cycle contains no vertex with label less than or equal to kğ‘˜k. Define the hull â„‹kâ€‹(ğ’¬)subscriptâ„‹ğ‘˜ğ’¬\mathcal{H}_{k}(\mathcal{Q}) by first adding to ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q} the edges of this maximal cycle and then removing all edges that lie in the unbounded component of the complement of the maximal cycle. We obtain a quadrangulation of the cylinder of height kğ‘˜k with boundary sizes (p,qk)ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜(p,q_{k}), where qksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜q_{k} denotes the size of the maximal cycle. To make this correspondence precise, we need a convention for the position of the root: we can declare that in the filling of the slot, the root edge of the truncated quadrangulation corresponds to the added extra edge. Following [8], we say that a forest â„±â„±\mathcal{F} with a distinguished vertex is (h,p,q)â„ğ‘ğ‘(h,p,q)-admissible if

    the forest consists of an ordered sequence (ğ’¯1,ğ’¯2,â€¦,ğ’¯q)subscriptğ’¯1subscriptğ’¯2â€¦subscriptğ’¯ğ‘({\mathcal{T}}_{1},{\mathcal{T}}_{2},\ldots,{\mathcal{T}}_{q}) of qğ‘q (rooted) plane trees,

  2. (ii)

    the maximal height of these trees is hâ„h,

  3. (iii)

    the total number of vertices of the forest at generation hâ„h is pğ‘p,

  4. (iv)

    the distinguished vertex has height hâ„h and belongs to ğ’¯1subscriptğ’¯1{\mathcal{T}}_{1}.

If â„±â„±\mathcal{F} is a (h,p,q)â„ğ‘ğ‘(h,p,q)-admissible forest, we write â„±âˆ—superscriptâ„±\mathcal{F}^{*} for the set all vertices of â„±â„±\mathcal{F} at height strictly less than hâ„h. We write ğ”½h,p,qâˆ˜subscriptsuperscriptğ”½â„ğ‘ğ‘{\mathbb{F}}^{\circ}_{h,p,q} for the set of all (h,p,q)â„ğ‘ğ‘(h,p,q)-admissible forests.

The preceding discussion yields a bijection between, on the one hand, truncated quadrangulations ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q} of the cylinder of height hâ„h with boundary sizes (p,q)ğ‘ğ‘(p,q), and, on the other hand, pairs consisting of a (h,p,q)â„ğ‘ğ‘(h,p,q)-admissible forest â„±â„±\mathcal{F} and a collection (Mv)vâˆˆâ„±âˆ—subscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘£ğ‘£superscriptâ„±(M_{v})_{v\in\mathcal{F}^{*}} such that, for every vâˆˆâ„±âˆ—ğ‘£superscriptâ„±v\in\mathcal{F}^{*}, Mvsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘£M_{v} is a truncated quadrangulation with boundary size cv+1subscriptğ‘ğ‘£1c_{v}+1, if cvsubscriptğ‘ğ‘£c_{v} stands for the number of children of vğ‘£v in â„±â„±\mathcal{F}. We call this bijection the skeleton decomposition and we say that â„±â„±\mathcal{F} is the skeleton of the quadrangulation ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q}.

It will also be convenient to use the notation ğ”½h,p,qsubscriptğ”½â„ğ‘ğ‘{\mathbb{F}}_{h,p,q} for the set of all (ordered) forests, with no distinguished vertex, that satisfy properties (i),(ii),(iii) above. If â„±âˆˆğ”½h,p,qâ„±subscriptğ”½â„ğ‘ğ‘\mathcal{F}\in{\mathbb{F}}_{h,p,q}, we keep the notation â„±âˆ—superscriptâ„±\mathcal{F}^{*} for the set all vertices of â„±â„±\mathcal{F} at height strictly less than hâ„h.

We also set, for every pâ‰¥1ğ‘1p\geq 1, hâ‰¥1â„1h\geq 1,

ğ”½h,pâˆ˜=â‹ƒqâ‰¥1ğ”½h,p,qâˆ˜,ğ”½h,p=â‹ƒqâ‰¥1ğ”½h,p,q.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptğ”½â„ğ‘subscriptğ‘1subscriptsuperscriptğ”½â„ğ‘ğ‘subscriptğ”½â„ğ‘subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ”½â„ğ‘ğ‘{\mathbb{F}}^{\circ}_{h,p}=\bigcup_{q\geq 1}{\mathbb{F}}^{\circ}_{h,p,q}\;,\qquad{\mathbb{F}}_{h,p}=\bigcup_{q\geq 1}{\mathbb{F}}_{h,p,q}.

We conclude this section with a useful observation about connections between the truncated hull and the standard hull of the UIPQ. Consider two integers uğ‘¢u and rğ‘Ÿr with 1â‰¤u<r1ğ‘¢ğ‘Ÿ1\leq u<r. Recall that the truncated hull â„‹rtrsubscriptsuperscriptâ„‹trğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{r} is viewed as a truncated quadrangulation of the cylinder of height rğ‘Ÿr, whose top cycle is ğ’rsubscriptğ’ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{C}_{r}. Write â„±(r)âˆ˜subscriptsuperscriptâ„±ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{F}^{\circ}_{(r)} for the skeleton of this truncated quadrangulation, and also consider the cycle âˆ‚uâ„‹rtrsubscriptğ‘¢subscriptsuperscriptâ„‹trğ‘Ÿ\partial_{u}\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{r}, which by construction coincides with ğ’usubscriptğ’ğ‘¢\mathcal{C}_{u}. Vertices of this cycle are at distance uğ‘¢u from the root vertex of the UIPQ, and may or may not belong to the boundary of the standard hull of radius uğ‘¢u. 2.4 Geodesics in the skeleton decomposition

Consider again a quadrangulation ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q} of the cylinder of height hâ‰¥2â„2h\geq 2 with boundary sizes (p,q)ğ‘ğ‘(p,q). 2.7 The law of the perimeter of hulls

We still have to prove Proposition 15. We note that the continuous analog of the UIPQ, or of the UIPT, is the Brownian plane introduced in [5]. For every r>0ğ‘Ÿ0r>0 the definition of the hull of radius rğ‘Ÿr makes sense in the Brownian plane and the explicit distribution of the volume of the hull was computed in [6], showing in particular that the expected volume is finite and (by scaling invariance) equal to a constant times r4superscriptğ‘Ÿ4r^{4}. On the other hand, in the case of the UIPT, MÃ©nard [19] was recently able to compute the exact distribution of the volume of hulls. Such an exact expression is not yet available in the case of the UIPQ, and so we use a different method based on the skeleton decomposition.

Before we proceed to the proof of Proposition 15, we state a lemma concerning truncated quadrangulations with a Boltzmann distribution. Let pâ‰¥1ğ‘1p\geq 1. We say that a random truncated quadrangulation ğŒğŒ\mathbf{M} with boundary size pâ‰¥1ğ‘1p\geq 1 is Boltzmann distributed if, for every integer nâ‰¥1ğ‘›1n\geq 1, for every â„³âˆˆâ„šn,ptrâ„³subscriptsuperscriptâ„štrğ‘›ğ‘\mathcal{M}\in{\mathbb{Q}}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{n,p}, â„™â€‹(ğŒ=â„³)=Zâ€‹(p)âˆ’1â€‹â€‰12âˆ’nâ„™ğŒâ„³ğ‘superscriptğ‘1superscript12ğ‘›{\mathbb{P}}(\mathbf{M}=\mathcal{M})=Z(p)^{-1}\,12^{-n}.
